title: 114_hr3295
content:
The Department of Justice is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance for fiscal year 2015. This includes funding for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, including public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for grants to State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for precursor chemicals and methamphetamine, and $15,000,000 for grants to statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for investigative purposes related to heroin and opioid distribution. INDEPENDENT AGENCIES

Small Business Administration: $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans program account.

DEPARTMENT OF LABOR

Employment and Training Administration: $265,000,000 for training and employment services.

DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES

Health Resources and Services Administration: $50,000,000 for maternal and child health under the Healthy Start Initiative. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration receives $10,000,000 for drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. The Community Planning and Development fund includes a transfer of funds. $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund until September 30, 2016, to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be granted to distressed communities based on specific criteria determined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Community Development Fund allocates $500,000,000 until September 30, 2016, to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage for approval by the Secretary, with specific criteria for eligibility and long-term recovery goals. The Secretary will specify approval criteria within 45 days of enactment, and funds will not affect non-emergency formula allocations. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for any statute or regulation in connection with fund obligations, except for fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment, if good cause exists and it aligns with the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. The Secretary can use up to 30% of funds for immediate community assistance and up to $10,000,000 for administrative costs under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028, with certain conditions. Agencies must report financial data for policy evaluation. The Act provides emergency funding designated by Congress, subject to the President's approval. It is known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
